The conversion of CO 2 into valuable chemicals utilizing solar energy is one of the most promising approaches to solve the problems associated with global warming and energy shortage.Considering more and more covalent organic frameworks (COFs) that have been reported, the great potential of COFs as photocatalysts for CO 2 reduction is still appreciated to a limited extent.In the current work, Ru nanoparticles (NPs) loaded ketoaminebased COF (TpPa-1) catalysts, named RuTpPa-1, were developed for the

(32.4 mol g cat -1 h -1 ).The photocatalytic activity is inferior to most of the reported photocatalytic systems coupled with Re or Ru complexes as photosensitizers, but competitive with some representative MOF-based photocatalysts under similar conditions (Table S1).To verify the origin of the produced HCOOH, Ar instead of CO 2 as the reactant was introduced into the reaction system using 3.0 wt RuTpPa-1 as the photocatalyst under otherwise similar conditions and no hydrocarbon production was

(electron withdraw) that can enhance the carbon-oxygen bonding force, including Ru NPs, to a certain extent inclines to form HCOOH 66.As control experiments, no reaction took place in dark or without catalyst, demonstrating a truly photocatalytic behavior.Compared to TpPa-1, RuTpPa-1 catalysts are more active.One can see that the maximum yield of HCOOH produced in 10 h can be up to 108.8 mol g cat -1 h -1 over 3.0 wt RuTpPa-1, much higher than that observed over TpPa-1 (32.4 mol g cat -1 h -1 ).The

Please find the category of Light_source and Lamp from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.
Please only select the generation from the provided possible choices.
Possible Choices:
Light_source: ['UV', 'Solar', 'UV-Vis', 'Monochromatic', 'Solar Simulator']
Lamp: ['Fluorescent', 'Mercury', 'Halogen', 'Mercury-Xenon', 'LED', 'Tungsten', 'Xenon', 'Tungsten-Halide', 'Solar Simulator']
